newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan's Sakakibara says no target zone for yen.
newsitem.headline: Japan's Sakakibara says no target zone for yen.

text.p: Eisuke Sakakibara, director-general of the Japanese Finance Ministry's International Finance Bureau denied on Thursday that he previously said he wants to see the Japanese yen at 108 to 110 to the dollar.

Speaking in a television interview with TV Tokyo, the influential official said: "There was a rumour today that Japan was trying to maneuver the yen to between 108 yen and 110 yen but this is completely groundless. I have not said such a thing to anybody. We don't have a target zone."
"We are not thinking of guiding the foreign exchange rate to a certain zone," he said.
"The Japanese government's foreign exchange policy has not changed," he said. He added that this was also true for the United States and other G7 countries.
He also said that Japan was watching movements in the foreign exchange markets carefully.
Market participants have been keeping a close eye on Sakakibara as his comments in early November, after the dollar hit this year's high of 114.92 yen, pushed it down sharply.
He had said back then that the market view on Japan's economy was too pessimistic and that he believed it was stronger than the market thought.

Sakakibara, dubbed "Mr Yen" by the foreign media, is said to have been the key figure in driving the dollar above 100 yen last year through aggressive government intervention in foreign exchange markets.
